[[Yitzhak Rabin]] | commander2 = [[Glubb Pasha]] | strength1 = 6,000 | strength2 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = }} '''Operation Danni''' ({{lang-he|מבצע דני}}, ''Mivtza Dani'') was an [[Israeli military]] offensive launched at the end of the first truce of the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]]. The objectives were to capture territory east of [[Tel Aviv]] and then to push inland and relieve the [[Jew]]ish population and forces in [[Jerusalem]]. The main forces fighting against the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] were the [[Arab Legion]] and Palestinian irregulars Chaim Herzog, 'The Arab-Israeli Wars' ISBN 0-85368-367-0 (1982). page 80: 'A blow against the Arab Legion was the essence of Operation 'Danny' planned as the main Israeli offensive to be mounted on the resumption of hostilities.' It was launched at the end of the [[1948 Arab-Israeli War#First truce (11 June 1948–8 July 1948)|first truce]], July 9–19, 1948. On 10 July, [[Glubb Pasha]] ordered the defending [[Arab Legion]] troops to "make arrangements...for a phony war".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CC7381HrLqcC&pg=PA287|title=1948|publisher=}} The operation commander was [[Yigal Allon]] and his deputy was [[Yitzhak Rabin]]. The total force numbered around 6,000 men.Kimche, Jon and David (1960) ''A Clash of Destinies. The Arab-Jewish War and the Founding of the State of Israel.'' Frederick A. Praeger. Library of Congress number 60-6996. Page 225:"largest force yet assembled under one Israeli." Itzhak Sade Yigal Alon.jpg|[[Yitzhak Sadeh]] (left) and [[Yigal Allon]] (1948) Palmach Lydda.jpg|[[8th Armored Brigade (Israel)|8th Armoured Brigade]] capture [[Ben Gurion Airport|Lydda Airport]] (1948) ==Name== The operation was named after [[Palmach]] officer [[Daniel Mass|Daniel "Dani" Mass]], who had fallen on January 16, 1948 while commanding a relief action known as "[[Convoy of 35]]". ==Objectives== The first phase of Operation Dani was to capture the cities of [[Lod|Lydda]] and [[Ramle]], located on the road to [[Jerusalem]], southeast of [[Tel Aviv]]. Ramle was one of the main obstacles blocking Jewish transportation.Golan, Arnon. "Lydda and Ramle: from Palestinian-Arab to Israeli towns, 1948-67," Middle Eastern Studies, October 1, 2003 From the start of the war, Lydda and Ramle militiamen had attacked Jewish traffic on nearby roads.Morris 2004, p. 424 Ramle became a focal point for blocking Jewish transportation, forcing traffic from Jerusalem to Tel Aviv to a southern bypass.[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-111203784.html Lydda and Ramle: from Palestinian-Arab to Israeli towns, 1948-67]. by Golan, Arnon The second phase was to capture the fort at [[Latrun]] and break through [[Ramallah]]. The operation was carried out under [[Palmach]] command using the [[Yiftach Brigade]], the [[Harel Brigade]], the [[8th Armored Brigade (Israel)|8th Armored Brigade]] and two [[battalions]] from the [[Kiryati Brigade|Kiryati]] and [[Alexandroni Brigade|Alexandroni]] [[brigades]]. ===Lydda and Ramle=== {{main article|1948 Palestinian exodus from Lydda and Ramle}} [[File:PikiWiki Israel 20793 The Palmach.jpg|thumb|[[Palmach]] (Yiftach brigade) soldiers with a (just destroyed by a [[PIAT]]) captured Jordanian army armored car, Operation Dani . 15 July 1948]] On 9 July units from the Yiftach Brigade began approaching Ramle from the south. At the same time troops from the other brigades began attacking villages north of Lydda. Caught in a pincer movement and with only a token Arab Legion presence the two towns were captured the following day. This put [[Ben Gurion Airport|Lydda airport]] and the strategic railway station at Ramle in Israeli hands. Two days after the capture of Lydda and Ramle only a few hundred of the 50,000 to 70,000 residents remained in the two towns. ===Latrun=== {{main article|Battles of Latrun (1948)}} [[File:Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.jpg|thumb|Road from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.]] The second phase of the operation failed after several costly attacks on Arab Legion positions at [[Battle of Latrun|Latrun]] and the threat of a [[UN]]-imposed cease-fire.Herzog, page 82. ===Casualties=== The Palmach record the names of ninety-one of its members killed during this Operation. Forty-four were killed at [[Shilta|Khirbet Kurikur]] on 18 July 1948. Seven were killed in the capture of Lydda.{{cite web|url=http://www.palmach.org.il/show_item.asp?itemId=8519&levelId=42855&itemType=0|title=פלמ"ח|publisher=}} ==Palestinian communities captured== (Most of the villages were systematically destroyed shortly after capture){{citation needed|date=May 2015}} {| class="wikitable" !Name!!Date!!Defending forces!!Brigade!!Population |- | [[Dayr Tarif]] | 9 July 1948 | Arab Legion | Armoured Brigade
